to_know.title: Good to know
to_know.1:
Right now, RootDB support MySQL, MariaDB and PostgreSQL databases.
Support for another database types, like Microsoft SQL server, are on the way.
to_know.2: RootDB support encrypted connection to remote databases. (if your database is not hosted on the same server.)

report_data_view_configuration.0: A report can contains one or more different types of views, so you will need at least one view to display your data.
report_data_view_configuration.1: The name of the view as it will always appears in views dropdown selector - for developers.

report_data_view_configuration.3: Here you can select the type of view you want to create. Right now, it's a table or a graph.
report_data_view_configuration.4: This option can be used when you need to fetch lot's of rows, with lot's of data by row. You can get you results chunk by chunk with this option activated, specifying the number of rows contained in a chunk.
report_data_view_configuration.5: You have full access to two of the most popular chart libraries. The easiest to use is Chart.js
report_data_view_configuration.6: Then select the type of graph you want to use to have the javascript code bootstrapped for you. If you don't know but are already familiar with one library, you can choose custom where you will have to make yourself the javascript code.

report_parameters.title: Report parameters
report_parameters.subtitle: All what you need to know
report_parameters.summary: How-to setup parameters on a report, how-to create custom parameters.

to_know.title: Good to know
to_know.1: Reports can have input parameters. They allow, most of the time, to filter SQL queries by restricting them to date ranges, particular IDs...
to_know.2: When a new organization is configured, default input parameters are created. For example a date picker, yes/no checkboxes, generic text or number fields.
to_know.3: You can of course create your own input parameters and this helper is there to guide you.

input_parameters.title: Input parameters
input_parameters.1: To see the already existing input parameters, modify them or create new ones, click on the input parameters icon in the menu bar.
input_parameters.2: The first thing to do is to name your new parameter. This is the name that will appear in the parameter selection list, when you will, later, configure the parameters available for a report.
input_parameters.3: The parameter can have one or more default values. For example, if it is a simple text field, you can assign it a default value. If it's a multi-select type, you can assign one or more values to pre-select one or more default entries. (coma separated)
input_parameters.4:
Different types of parameters are available. This is what the parameter will look like: checkbox, simple text field, selection list...
When you select a type of parameter , an example SQL query shows you how to generate values for your parameter.
For example, if it's a checkbox or a selection list, you need to display the possible values the user will be able to select.
input_parameters.5: You must also specify which data type the parameter value will be.
input_parameters.6:
Your parameter must be linked - or not - to a connector.
That is to say:
If your parameter does not require a SQL query or the SQL query can run on any databases then you can choose the special "all connectors" connector.

But if your query is database dependent (because you need to fetch data in specific tables) - which will usually be the case, then you need to select the right connector, which will use the right database for your SQL query.
input_parameters.7: In this editor you can write one query allowing you to retrieve, generally, the couple code -> value which will be used to fill a selection list, checkbox options etc...
input_parameters.8: If you need to make a SQL query to retrieve the default value of a parameter, write it in this editor.
input_parameters.9: Finally, to check your parameter, you can click on the "preview" button to see what it will look like. If there are errors (SQL among others), check in the "Log" tab from the menu bar.

access_setup_report_parameters.title: Access the configuration of report parameters
access_setup_report_parameters.1: When you are in a report tab, display the report menu...
access_setup_report_parameters.2: ... and select the option "Configure input parameters"

add_report_parameters.title: Adding a parameter to the report
add_report_parameters.1: The first thing to do is to name your parameter. This is the name that will appear to users of your report when they display the popup allowing them to configure the various parameters of the report before execution.
add_report_parameters.2: In your SQL queries, you will be able to access the value of a parameter using the name of the variable that you have defined in this field: @variableName.
add_report_parameters.3: Select one of the input parameters that you created earlier.
add_report_parameters.4: If the parameter you have selected has a default value but is not suitable for this report, you can override this value here.
add_report_parameters.5: This option aligns the parameters horizontally because, by default, the parameters are displayed one below the other.
add_report_parameters.6: If this report is integrated into an external website, you have the possibility of hiding a parameter. Because you can very well integrate the report with fixed parameters and, consequently, wish that user can modify only certain parameters and not others.

to_know.title: Good to know
to_know.1: The application is tabs based, so you can open multiple reports at the same time.

home_tab.title: Home tab
home_tab.1: User menu where you will be able to setup some preferences, update your user profil, access to administration modules, if your user has the rights, see current RootDB version and link to release not if an update is available, and logout.
home_tab.2: The left sidebar allows you to quickly filter reports by directory as well as search for a specific directory.
home_tab.3: You can search for a report by its name by clicking on the magnifying glass in the header menu bar.
home_tab.4: By clicking on the icons representing folders you can fold / unfold the entire tree structure of a directory.
home_tab.5: Allows you to add a report to your list of favorite reports, which you can find by selecting Favorites in the left sidebar.
home_tab.6: If a report has parameters, click this icon to view & configure the parameters and run the report.
home_tab.7: This icon is used to run the report default parameters. (if it has any)

report_tab.title: Report tab
report_tab.1: When you display a report, you find the same options as in the Home tab, but this time in the header menu bar.
report_tab.2: So you can change the report parameters easily.

home_tab_as_dev.title: Home tab as a developer
home_tab_as_dev.1: You can display the report configuration module directly from this tab, without having to open it.
home_tab_as_dev.2: It is possible to directly edit a particular view by selecting it from the drop-down list that will be displayed by clicking on the icon representing a pencil.
home_tab_as_dev.3: Click on the screen icon in the menu bar to display the SQL console in a new tab.
home_tab_as_dev.4: This is the location where you can create input parameters for your reports. Please checkthe "Report parameters" help for more information.
home_tab_as_dev.5: To create a report. Please check the "Your first report" help for more information.
home_tab_as_dev.6: The debug bar will allow you to see everything that happens at the application level. Errors or events relating to reports will be displayed here. (SQL error, API side, javascript error etc... )

report_tab_as_dev.title: Report tab as a developer
report_tab_as_dev.1: You can run only one view at a time by clicking here.
report_tab_as_dev.2: The pencil icon will allow you to switch to view editing mode.
report_tab_as_dev.3: Will display the view configuration module.
report_tab_as_dev.4: And you can delete a view directly here.

access_report_link_configuration.title: Access the link configuration form
access_report_link_configuration.1: Edit the view containing the table and click on the tab containing the options related to the display of the columns.
access_report_link_configuration.2: After expanding the column's options for which you want to add a link or more, click on the "Links to reports" button.

report_link_configuration.title: Configuring a link
report_link_configuration.1:
You can give a label to the link you are going to create.
This is useful if the column contains several links, because since these links will be displayed in a popup, they must have a label in order to differentiate them.
But if the column contains only one link, then no popup is displayed.
The link will be appended on the value of the column, with an link icon.
report_link_configuration.2: Selection of the targeted report. Note that you will only be able to select reports containing input parameters in this drop-down list.
report_link_configuration.3:
Once the target report is selected, all of its input parameters will be listed.
They will be appended to the URL when the user clicks on the link.
You have the option to skip any parameters so that they are not present in the URL.

4.1: For each parameter you must indicate how to retrieve its value:
4.2: If you select "Column value", the value used for this parameter will correspond to the value of one of the columns of this report, to be selected from the drop-down list on the right.
4.3: If you select "Report parameter", the value used for this parameter will correspond to one of the input parameters of this report, to be selected in the drop-down list on the right.

link_same_report.title: Create a link to the same report
link_same_report.1: When the target report you have selected is the same as the one you are editing, then you have the option to make this link open in the same tab.<br/ >This will allow users to filter the report more quickly, without going through the popup containing all the input parameters.

0.title: Welcome to RootDB
0.2: This ownerâ€™s tour aims at introducing you to everything you need to know to start reporting with RootDB: the terminology used, the structure of a report and the essential points of the user interface.
0.3: You can access this presentation at any time from the user menu.

1.title: Connector, report & data view
1.2: one or more data views to display data in the form, mainly, of tables or graphs.
1.3: SQL queries executed before/after view rendering to initialize temporary variables or tables that can be used in view SQL queries.
1.4: input parameters, in order to filter data fetched from the database. Parameters values can be used in the SQL queries.
1.5: A view is made up of 3 elements:
1.6: a SQL query, to retrieve the data.
1.7: javascript code in the case of a chart or a configuration interface in the case of a table.
1.8: the data view, strictly speaking: a graph or a table.
1.9: First of all you will have to configure at least one connector that represents a database connection. (Mysql/MariaDB/PostgreSQL for now)
1.10: Once the connector is created, you will be able to start creating reports.

2.title: It's root
2.1: Regarding the way data is retrieved and the charts created, RootDB has chosen to give as much freedom to the developer, which implies that he must know:
2.2: the SQL language - because yes, well-mastered, it allows us to do a lot of things.
2.3: how to use javascript because RootDB gives full access to Chart.js or D3.js - thus allowing direct use of the official documentation from these two libraries.
2.4: Note that RootDB provides ready-to-use chart templates with sample SQL query for the most common charts. This allows you to have a javascript code base on which you can develop the graph's functionalities, if necessary.

3.title: Menu bar
3.1: User menu where you can configure some preferences, update your profile, access administration module (if your user has access rights), see the current version of RootDB and a link to the release notes, when an update is available.
3.2: Opens the Help tab, containing everything you need to know about report creation.
3.3: Displays the Home tab, which lists all available reports.
3.4: Opens a SQL console, with a display of database tables and views. You will also be able to create draft SQL queries.
3.5: Displays the log tab, allowing you to display application logs and filter them by report.
3.7: Search for a report by clicking here.

4.title: Report launch and management options
4.1: Run the report directly, using the default input parameters. (if any)
4.2: Allows you to configure the input parameters of the report and run it.
4.3: Add or remove this report from favorites.
4.4: Open report configuration window. (title, description, visibility, location, permissions, sharing options...)
4.5: Allows you to directly select a view in order to edit its code.

5.title: Report tab
5.1: Here you will find the main menu of the report in order to manage its views, configure it, manage its input parameters or edit the initialization or cleanup SQL queries.
5.2: Report visibility indicator. By default it is only visible to the developer. You can click here to make it visible, or not.
5.6: Since it is possible to have the same report open in several tabs, you can see the input parameters used in each tab by pressing the tab, in mobile mode, or by hovering your mouse over the tab.

6.title: View options
6.1: To delete the view of a report. (with confirmation popup)
6.3: Edit the SQL / javascript code of the view.
6.5: Export data to CSV, only available for table type view.
